challenges-to-voters-at-the-polling-plac.name: Challenges to Voters at the Polling Place

citations: Per Oklahoma State Election Board, September 2012.
subtopics.fact: A voter's right to vote or register to vote cannot be challenged at any point in the registration or voting process. If there is any question of the voter's eligibilty, for example if their name is not on the registry for the precinct, they should be offered a provisional ballot.
All voters who vote in person on Election Day or during early voting
subtopics.subtopic: Who must show ID to vote?

subtopics.fact:
An ID must have been issued by the U.S. government, the state of Oklahoma or a federally recognized tribal government. Examples include:
  • An Oklahoma driver's license
  • An Oklahoma state ID card
  • A U.S. passport
  • A military ID
  • The voter ID card issued by the Board of Elections
An ID must contain the voter's name, photograph and an expiration date (which must be after Election Day), except a voter ID card that does not meet all these requirements is still acceptable. IDs issued to people 65 and older without an expiration date are acceptable.

Voters without ID may cast a provisional ballot. They must fill out and sign an affidavit that explains why the provisional ballot should be counted, which the county election board will use to determine whether to count the provisional ballot.
subtopics.subtopic: If a voter has no ID, are there alternatives such as an oath or witness?

citations: Per Oklahoma State Election Board, September 2012.
subtopics.fact: Yes, as long as it is issued by a public institution of higher education, shows the voter's name and photograph and contains an expiration date after Election Day.
subtopics.subtopic: Is a student ID an acceptable form of identification?

citations: Per Oklahoma State Election Board, September 2012.
subtopics.fact: No. Oklahoma's law on voter ID does not mention the voter's address. The law does not require that the document used for identification include the address of registration.
subtopics.subtopic: Does the ID have to show the address at which a voter is registered to vote?
Do elections without federal offices on the ballot (such as off-year gubernatorial elections) have different ID requirements?
